posts.text:
Google's leaked documents confirmed it.

They use a secret metric called siteAuthority to determine who to trust.

The sites dominating search in 2025 and beyond aren't chasing keywords. They're owning entire topics.

7-step framework for building topical authority:

1. Define your core topic domain

Pick a niche you can actually dominate. "Email marketing" is too broad. "Email marketing for SaaS companies" works. Most people fail here by going too wide.

2. Uncover your entire topic universe

Map every subtopic and user question. Use Reddit, Quora, People Also Ask, competitor analysis. You need 1,000s of keywords, not 20.

3. Group keywords into content clusters

Use SERP-based clustering. If two keywords show 70%+ overlap in top-ranking URLs, they belong on the same page. Pattern-based tools miss this completely.

Tool tip: I cluster keywords with Keyword Insights.

4. Architect topic hubs

Create pillar pages for broad topics. Build cluster pages for specific subtopics. Internally link them both ways. This signals comprehensive coverage to Google.

5. Execute content gap analysis

Find every cluster where competitors rank, but you don't. Prioritize by search volume and difficulty. These are your highest-ROI opportunities.

6. Create content with information gain

Add unique value. Original research, firsthand experience, expert analysis. AI 'consensus' content doesn't tend to build authority.

7. Weave strategic internal links

Hub-and-spoke model. Every cluster links to its pillar. Every pillar links to all clusters. No page should be orphaned (left on its own).

Sites that master this see 57% faster traffic growth than those that don't (Graphite, 2024).

The question isn't whether to build topical authority.

It's whether you'll build it before your competitors do.

We used this for Kleo. Hit $61K MRR in 53 days.

The framework: Content ‚Üí Email ‚Üí Webinar

Create "edusales" content that subtly teases your product. Don't hard sell. Lead with value. Plug your tool in ONE bullet point.

Hit $61K MRR before even launching publicly.

Stack your calendar with customer calls. Use first 500 users to iterate. Then relaunch to second cohort at a higher price.

Playbook 2: The Wave Surfer Strategy

TrustMR by Marc Lou: $24K MRR in 30 days.

Pieter Levels tweeted, complaining about fake MRR screenshots on X.

Marc shipped TrustMRR within 48 hours.

He didn't use his own audience. He piggybacked on Pieter‚Äôs virality.

Ship fast. Quit fast if it doesn't work.

Build virality into the product. TrustMRR is inherently shareable.

When you get massive attention but low intent, sell ads instead of subscriptions.

Playbook 3: Language Arbitrage Strategy

They took Kajabi/Teachable and made it 100% French.

That's it. Same product. Different language.

SEO in other languages = marketing on easy mode. High volume. Low competition. It's what SEO in English looked like in the early 2000s.

The AI revolution isn't killing SEO. It's creating new opportunities for companies willing to adapt.

The biggest opportunity?

Even early-stage companies can win immediately.

You don't need domain authority like Google. You just need to get cited and you‚Äôll start showing up.

posts.text:
How does AI search actually work today?

This is what happens between ask and answer:

Unlike older models that leaned on recall, GPT-5 grounds answers in live sources with a search-and-verify loop.

1. Your Question

Uses chat history and general location for relevance.

2. Decide to Search

If the model needs fresh, verifiable, or comparative info, it turns on search.

3. Plan Search

Breaks your ask into sub-queries, chooses a provider, sets recency or domain limits.

4A. Web Retrieval

Hits a search index with keywords and vectors, re-ranks for relevance, freshness, and diversity, and returns candidate URLs/snippets.

4B‚ÄìF. Where that index comes from

- Websites: Public pages and feeds
- Collect Pages: Crawlers/APIs fetch, follow robots.txt
- Clean & Split: Strip boilerplate; chunk with metadata
- Index for Search: Make embeddings; add entities/links
- Search Index: Searchable store for keyword and vector

5. Open Pages

Fetches the chosen URLs, renders HTML, follows redirects, normalizes canonicals.

6. Evidence

Pulls clean, cited snippets with dates and URLs; filters out duplicates.

7. Write Answer

Composes from the evidence; can add steps, tables, comparisons, citations.

8. Quality Check

Groundedness and policy screens; flags conflicting claims across sources.

9. Answer

Final explanation with sources and follow-ups. Clicks and re-asks feed a small feedback loop for better routing next time.

Curious to know how you show up in AI answers?

Use Mentions.

posts.text:
I‚Äôm seeing tons of misleading SEO advice for AI search.

Let‚Äôs bust 5 of the biggest myths:

1. ‚ÄúYou need to write in a special way for LLMs to understand you‚Äù

LLMs are trained on billions of examples of natural language: conversations, books, web pages, social media. They learn patterns, context, and slang the way people actually write.

That makes them robust to typos, casual grammar, and everyday phrasing. In other words: they‚Äôre built to process normal human language, not rigid SEO-style writing.

2. ‚ÄúAdding an llms.txt file will improve visibility in AI search results‚Äù

llms.txt is not a ranking factor. It‚Äôs a proposed standard for telling AI models what they can or can‚Äôt use, but most don‚Äôt even honor it.

Publishing one doesn‚Äôt boost how often you show up in AI answers, visibility comes from shaping your brand narrative across sites, communities, and trusted sources, not from a text file.

3. ‚ÄúAI will reliably use schema markup to generate answers‚Äù

Schema is intended as a hint, not a guarantee. Most LLMs don‚Äôt consistently parse schema, often ignore it when conflicting content exists, or give higher weight to context from non-schema sources.

Presence of schema does not assure inclusion in generated answers.

4. ‚ÄúLLMs just pulls from the first page of Google results‚Äù

AI answers don‚Äôt simply mirror the SERP. Yes, there‚Äôs overlap with the top 10 results, but it varies a lot:

- Perplexity: 82% overlap
- Google AI Mode: 35% overlap
- ChatGPT: 28% overlap

And beyond SERPs, 40% of AI answers come from Reddit and other community-driven sources. Meaning: ranking on page one isn‚Äôt enough, visibility in AI requires presence across forums, news, and niche sites too.

5. ‚ÄúYou need special tactics to win spots in AI Overviews‚Äù

Google has been clear that there isn‚Äôt a hidden trick. AI Overviews rely on the same fundamentals as organic search: high-quality, relevant, authoritative content.

If your pages already perform well in traditional search, they‚Äôre eligible to be surfaced in AI Overviews. What matters is clarity, expertise, and trustworthiness, not special tactics or gimmicks.

Did I miss any big myths you‚Äôve seen?

If you rank in the top 10, you‚Äôre very likely to be cited.

Rankings strongly predict citations (slightly looser at the exact URL level).

54% domain overlap / 35% URL overlap.

45% domain overlap / 28% URL overlap.

Low correlation. It draws from communities and reference hubs (such as Reddit, Wikipedia, and YouTube) more than the current top 10.

ChatGPT‚Äôs correlation is stronger with Bing than with Google.

Analyzed 5,000 queries and counted the overlapping domains and URLs between the 4 AI platforms and Google‚Äôs top 10 organic rankings. Links in the comments.

GPT-5 just made SEO indispensable.

Here‚Äôs how:

(This graphic was created to visualize how GPT-5 and SEO work together after reading Dan Petrovic‚Äôs incredible article. Link in comments.)

1. GPT-5 isn‚Äôt built to memorize the world‚Äôs knowledge.

OpenAI deliberately designed it to be a reasoning engine, a brain on top of tools. Instead of hoarding facts, it retrieves them in real time.

2. Grounding is everything.

Nick Turley from OpenAI put it best:

‚ÄúThe right product is LLMs connected to ground truth, and that‚Äôs why we brought search to ChatGPT and I think that makes a huge difference.‚Äù

Without grounding, GPT-5 is virtually useless.

3. That is where SEO comes in.

If your content isn‚Äôt discoverable, optimized, and credible, GPT-5 (along with every other LLM) can‚Äôt use it.

SEO is the oxygen. GPT-5 is the brain.

The brain (reasoning engine) can think, but without oxygen (SEO content), it can‚Äôt survive.

Grounding is the lungs, pulling in air (information) in real time.

But the quality of that air depends on SEO.

GPT-5 has made SEO the foundation of AI search.

posts.text:
The vase story is the ultimate marketing lesson.

A ceramics teacher split their class in two:

Group A was graded on quantity. Make as many vases as possible.

Group B was graded on quality. Make just one perfect vase.

At the end of the term, the best vases came from the quantity group.

Why?

Because while one group was sketching the ‚Äúperfect‚Äù vase, the other group was making, failing, learning, improving.

That‚Äôs exactly how marketing works.

You don‚Äôt find the perfect campaign in a deck.

You find it in the field.

Quantity-first marketers launch campaigns, test angles, push content, run ads, gather data.

Every experiment is a ‚Äúvase‚Äù. They learn fast, double down on what works, cut what doesn‚Äôt.

Quality-first marketers try to build the perfect campaign before launch. Endless brainstorms, revisions, and decks.

By the time it‚Äôs live, the market has already shifted, and they‚Äôve learned nothing in the process.

The best marketers aren‚Äôt the ones with the prettiest presentations.

They‚Äôre the ones running more experiments than everyone else.

Quantity breeds quality.

10 prompts that turn 5 hours of SEO into 5 minutes:

1. SEO Audit

Act as an expert SEO consultant. Audit the website {DOMAIN}. Identify key issues across technical SEO, content gaps, on-page optimization, backlinks, and UX. Then prioritize top fixes and opportunities.

2. TASM (Total Addressable Search Market)

Help me define the Total Addressable Search Market for {PRODUCT/SERVICE/DOMAIN}. Group keywords into TOFU/MOFU/BOFU clusters. Include intent, content types, and estimated opportunity.

3. Search Intent Reverse Engineering

For the keyword ‚Äò{KEYWORD}‚Äô, analyze search intent. Break it into primary and secondary user goals. Suggest ideal content format, page structure, and CTA strategy.

4. Programmatic SEO Template Generator

Create a reusable SEO article template for ‚Äò{KEYWORD FRAMEWORK}‚Äô, designed for programmatic generation. Include intro, modular blocks (tables, FAQs, lists), and recommended internal/external links.

5. Entity-Optimized Article Creator

Write a long-form article for the keyword ‚Äò{KEYWORD}'. Optimize for AI Overviews and semantic SEO. Include entities, subtopics, FAQs, and a concise summary answer at the top.

6. Topical Authority Builder

Build a topical map for the niche ‚Äò{NICHE}‚Äô. Show the main pillar pages, cluster topics, and long-tail supporting articles needed to build topical authority.

7. SERP Competitor Teardown

Analyze the top 10 Google results for ‚Äò{KEYWORD}'. Summarize shared features like structure, word count, format, visuals, and metadata. Then suggest how to differentiate and outperform.

8. BOFU Content Finder

Act as a B2B SEO strategist. For the product/service ‚Äò{YOUR PRODUCT OR OFFER}‚Äô, list 15 BOFU keywords that signal strong purchase intent. Include variations like ‚Äòbest‚Äô, ‚Äòvs‚Äô, ‚Äòreview‚Äô, ‚Äòalternative‚Äô, ‚Äòpricing‚Äô, ‚Äòtool‚Äô, ‚Äòagency‚Äô, and buyer pain points.

9. LLM SEO

Optimize this article {LINK} for LLM platforms like ChatGPT and Google AI Overviews. Ensure clear entity associations, direct answers, source credibility, and formatting that‚Äôs easy to extract as a summary.

10. Untapped Demand

Act as an advanced SEO and product marketing strategist. For the audience {TARGET AUDIENCE} and product {YOUR PRODUCT}, list 20 ‚Äòzero-volume‚Äô or overlooked search queries that signal deep intent or pain. These should be phrased in natural language, question-based, or problem-first. Include use cases or scenarios.

posts.text:
Before: 300+ blog posts, 1K/mo (declining) traffic.

After: 0 new blog posts, 120K/mo traffic.

How? Content optimization.

Here's the background:

The client had published 300+ posts over 2 years, but only hit ~1K/mo traffic (and it was falling). They‚Äôd invested 6-figures and wanted more out of what they already had.

Here's what we did:

1. Content audit

We analyzed all 300+ posts and identified:

- Nearly-ranking posts (low-hanging fruit)
- Overlapping posts that could be merged
- Posts with potential but poorly optimized
- Content offering little/no value to users or Google
- Posts targeting multiple intents that should be split

We prioritized what could move the needle fastest.

2. Content optimization

We optimized content with the most potential (~20%).

For each, we improved:

- Introduction
- Internal linking
- SERP snippets
- Topic coverage
- Matching intent
- Term frequency
- Content structure

We completed this over a 90-day sprint.

And hit 120K+/mo in 180 days.

Publishing more isn‚Äôt always the answer.

Optimizing what you already have can drive bigger wins.

posts.text:
This is getting out of hand.

New SEO acronyms drop all the time, and we've certainly seen a lot of creativity over the last few months.

(Bonus points if you can name them all)

I‚Äôve been guilty too, trying to make sense of (or differentiate) AI and ‚Äúnew SEO‚Äù. Is it GEO? AEO? LEO?

Then I remembered the Midwit Razor:

What would the "idiot" and the "genius" agree on?

posts.text:
Traditional SEO was about backlinks.

LLM SEO is about mentions.

As search shifts from "10 blue links" to AI-generated answers, it‚Äôs about being part of the answer training set.

LLM SEO consists of 2 core strategies:

1. Earned = Mentions

LLMs like ChatGPT don‚Äôt pull answers out of thin air.

They generate responses by:

- Running a query
- Retrieving relevant URLs
- Summarizing from those pages

If your brand is consistently mentioned across those sources, you‚Äôre more likely to be included in the answer (even if your site isn‚Äôt the one being shown).

It‚Äôs the new version of link building.

But instead of asking:

"How do I get more backlinks?"

You‚Äôre asking:

"How do I get mentioned in content LLMs trust?"

You win by:

1. Identifying influential source URLs
2. Getting your brand mentioned by them
3. Monitoring your mentions across AI results

Tip: Use a tool like Mentions for steps 1 and 3.

2. Owned = Content

This is your own domain.

When you optimize your site to answer specific questions clearly (using Q&A blocks, semantic HTML, topic hubs), LLMs can lift your content directly into answers.

It‚Äôs like building a mini knowledge base.

But not for people... for LLMs.

Earned and owned together help you:

- Influence what LLMs know about you
- Control how you‚Äôre represented
- Stay visible as search shifts to conversations

So the real question now is:

‚ÄúAre you part of the answer training set?‚Äù

posts.text:
My 31-step SEO checklist for creating new blog posts:

Phase 1: Topic Research

Identify the primary keyword for your topic. This is typically the most popular keyword related to your topic.

Identify the secondary keywords for your topic. These are keywords closely related to your primary keyword.

Determine the intent of your topic. Search your primary keyword and analyze the pages Google is rewarding.

Ensure you can solve the searcher's problem. Your content should fulfil the searcher's query and solve their problem.

Phase 2: Content

Reverse engineer the current featured snippet and implement your own.

Write your blog post‚Äôs headings (H2-H4) by incorporating the primary and secondary keywords.

Reverse-engineer competitor content and add new headings based on what your competitors are covering.

Look for Google Autosuggest, People Also Ask, and Related Searches to find other search data you can include as headings/sections.

Add new headings and sections based on your knowledge of the topic and information gathered via ICPs.

Make sure the content flows, is skimmable, has good readability, and covers all subtopics.

Ensure images are compressed to <100KB (or as small as possible).

Link to relevant articles and optimize anchor text.

Use bullets, numbered lists, and tables where possible for clarity and readability.

Use short sentences and paragraphs for readability.

Phase 3: Optimization

Include CTAs relevant to the reader's awareness level and search intent.

Add a table of contents to the top of the page for better navigation.

Ensure the title is compelling and includes the primary keyword.

Ensure the URL is short, concise, and includes the primary keyword.

Check if the word count is within 200-400 words higher or lower than the top 1-4 competitor average. If not, ensure your content covers everything.

Write concise and descriptive alt-text for images.

Craft a meta description that is highly relevant to the topic and includes the primary keyword. Ensure it is between 150 and 160 characters and gives a reason for the user to click.

Avoid using the primary keyword more than once in H2-H6 headings to prevent over-optimization. Use secondary keywords and variations instead.

Hook the reader in the introduction by including the topic in the first sentence or paragraph.

Tie the conclusion back to the main topic.

Bold/italicise key text (sentences and/or paragraphs) for emphasis.

Include contextual external links to clarify jargon terms.

Link to any references used to cite your sources.

Run your final draft through an optimization tool like Clearscope, Surfer, or Frase.

Phase 4: New SEO

posts.text:
Please STOP publishing new blog posts.

I see too many websites with 100s of existing blog posts that get 0 traffic, yet they focus entirely on publishing new content every month.

If you already have existing content, do this instead:

- Go to Search Console
- Filter for the last 28 days
- Export your keyword data
- Filter keywords in positions 3-20
- Prioritize keywords to increase ranking

Then find ways to better optimize for those keywords within your existing content.

For example:

- Write new sections
- Add to existing sections
- Improve existing headings
- Optimize for snippets/AI Overviews

You will get quicker traffic increases by optimizing your existing content rather than creating new content.

Make this your focus and watch what happens.

posts.text:
Social media marketing vs search marketing:

(8 ways they are complete opposites)

Social users don‚Äôt have a plan.
Search users are taking action.

Social posts are typically short-form.
Search typically requires longer-form.

Social gets instant results after publishing.
Search results are delayed after publishing.

Social algorithms are focused on engagement.
Search algorithms are focused on relevance.

Social posts typically lose visibility after hours.
Search provides consistent and long-term traffic.

Social needs to align with the interests of followers.
Search needs to align with the intent of searchers.

Social gets fewer conversions but more awareness.
Search gets more conversions if you fulfil the query.

Social has viral potential as there‚Äôs no limit to reach.
Search traffic won‚Äôt exceed the number of searches.

They are complete opposites.

But when done right, they work incredibly well together.

Here's how:

- Create long-form content for SEO
- Repurpose and distribute it for socials
- Convert readers to email subscribers on both

That way, you leverage:

- Instant visibility with socials
- Long-term visibility with SEO
- Direct communication with email

What other differences would you add?

posts.text:
The best SEO masterclass you'll see this week.

7 strategies behind Canva's dominance:

- 270M monthly traffic
- 35M backlinks
- 190 target countries
- $100Ms SEO revenue
- $26B valuation

1. Programmatic SEO

Canva created 1,000s of SEO-focused pages at scale.

They're divided into 3 main categories:

- Builder (e.g. Resume Builder or Logo Maker)
- Templates (e.g. YouTube Banner Template)
- Create (e.g. Create Logo or Create CV)

These pages alone get 100M+ monthly SEO traffic.

And even a low 1% conversion rate acquires at least 1M new Canva users a month.

2. Product-Led Conversions

Canva converts traffic by providing tools to create what the user has searched for, directly on the page, with ready-made templates inside the product.

This aligns with their freemium model:

A. Converts traffic to start using the platform right away (on the highly valuable free plan).

B. Free plan users later upgrade to a paid plan to unlock even more features.

3. Content Clusters

Canva created groups of related pages that build topical authority around specific design topics.

For example:

Subfolder: /colors
Page: /colors/color-meanings
Subpage: /colors/color-meanings/blue

This is how you dominate your search market.

The 'Colors' cluster alone has 3.8K pages, all interlinked, which generates 2M monthly SEO traffic.

4. Internal Linking

Canva ensures that high-authority pages pass ‚Äòauthority‚Äô to relevant subpages through internal linking.

For example:

High authority page: Flyer Templates
Subpage link: Restaurant Flyer Templates

That single link makes the subpage rank.

5. Backlinks
Canva has 35M backlinks from 338K websites, resulting in a 93 Domain Rating.

Standard outreach and PR aside...

Here are 3 strategies they used to EARN backlinks:

A. Link-worthy content

High-quality content that other websites cite.

For example:

Page: Ultimate Guide to Font Combinations
Backlinks: 2.8K (organically)

B. App integrations

New apps consistently get listed on Canva.

These apps often create content around their Canva integration, which results in a backlink.

C. Acquisitions

Canva bought these websites:

Pexels: DR 92
Affinity: DR 82
Pixabay: DR 92
Flourish: DR 84
Leonardo: DR 76
Designify: DR 48
Unscreen: DR 65
Remove bg: DR 81
Smartmockups: DR 67

Now they all link to Canva's website.

Reminder: Build backlinks from all your owned websites. These are the easiest links you'll get.

6. Localized and Multilingual SEO

Canva localized versions of their website to target all languages and regions, making them a global behemoth.

For example:

Latin America = 34M monthly traffic
Indonesia = 12M monthly traffic
Brazil = 15M monthly traffic

7. Trending Content

Canva keeps up with trends to drive traffic for current high-demand, low-competition keywords.

For example:

During the pandemic, the search demand for 'Zoom Backgrounds' skyrocketed.

New page: Free Zoom Background Templates
Result: 100K+ new monthly SEO traffic

posts.text:
30-step SEO checklist for optimizing content:

(follow it and you WILL increase traffic)

Phase 1: Audit

Which pages and keywords do you need to optimize?
‚Ü≥ Identify pages declining in performance
‚Ü≥ Focus on keywords nearly ranking (positions 3-20)

Are you matching the intent?
‚Ü≥ Match the content type (e.g. blog vs landing page)
‚Ü≥ Match the content format (e.g. how-to vs list)

Can you do better than the current top 3 results?

Phase 2: Filling Gaps

What have your competitors covered that you haven‚Äôt?

What topics or entities are you missing (i.e. NLP terms)?
‚Ü≥ Use tools like Surfer or Frase to identify topic gaps

Can you write new sentences, paragraphs, or sections around the keywords you‚Äôre nearly ranking for?

What other search data can you include as new sections to rank for even more searches?
‚Ü≥ Analyse autosuggest, People Also Ask, and related searches directly in the SERP

Phase 3: Improvements

Do you have new data or info from customers, interviews, or similar that you can include to make the content even better?

Is the content organised in an optimal structure?
‚Ü≥ Ensure it flows, it‚Äôs skimmable, covers all subtopics, and has a good readability experience

Have you used enough images or other media (i.e. showing product in action)?

Have you used numbered or bullet lists where possible?

Have you used tables where possible?

Have you used short sentences and paragraphs, and removed any fluff?

Should you add a table of contents to the top of the page?

Phase 4: Optimization

Does your introduction hook the reader and include you target topic or keyword in the content?

Have you included the topic (to tie it back) in the conclusion or final section?

Can you optimize the headings using your target keyword(s)?

Have you over-optimized for the target keyword by using it more than once in headings?
‚Ü≥ Ensure you avoid keyword stuffing

Have you boldened the key text (sentences and/or paragraphs)?
‚Ü≥ Use bold and italics to emphasize important text

Is there a featured snippet you can win? If so, how?

Can you make the meta title more compelling for higher CTR?

Can you make your meta description more compelling to click?

Does your image alt-text concisely explain what the images are?

What relevant pages can you internally link from?

Are there any pages you can link to?

Are you including CTAs relevant to the reader‚Äôs awareness level or search intent?

Phase 5: ‚ÄúNew‚Äù SEO

Have you optimized for Google‚Äôs AI Overview?
‚Ü≥ Structure your content to be easily summarized by AI
‚Ü≥ Focus on concise answers and bullet points

Have you incorporated EEAT (Experience, Expertise, Authoritativeness, Trustworthiness)?
‚Ü≥ Highlight author credentials and link to authoritative sources to build trust

Have you adapted headings for voice search?
‚Ü≥ Use conversational language and question headings

Have you optimized for multi-device usability?
‚Ü≥  Ensure content is accessible and user-friendly across different devices

posts.text:
Planning new SEO content?

PLEASE do this first:

1. Get all your blog URLs into a spreadsheet.

Use Screaming Frog to crawl and export. It provides other useful information like titles and descriptions.

Connect further data sources:

- Ahrefs
- Google Analytics
- Google Search Console

2. Enter each URL into Google Search Console or Ahrefs and find its best-ranking keywords.

Add this data to the spreadsheet for each page:

- Primary keyword (your main keyword)
- Secondary keywords (variations and similar)
- Current position for your target keyword(s)

If a URL isn't ranking for anything?

Find the most relevant keywords using Ahrefs.

Then...

3. Audit each blog post and assign actions:

- Leave: Content that‚Äôs reached its full potential
- Merge: Cannibalising or extremely similar content
- Delete: Content that no longer offers value to users
- Update: Small changes to improve the performance
- Rewrite: Large changes to improve the performance

4. Spend a few weeks implementing these actions to get more out of your existing assets.

Prioritize updates and rewrites that have:

- Target keywords in positions 4-20
- Higher conversion and $ potential
- Easy improvement opportunities

Remember:

Not all of your content needs to be new. Look at your existing content first.

You're likely sitting on many quick wins.

posts.text:
Our 31-step SEO checklist for creating blog posts:

(Follow it and you WILL get traffic)

Phase 1: Topic Research

Identify the primary keyword for your topic. This is typically the most popular keyword related to your topic.

Identify the secondary keywords for your topic. These are keywords closely related to your primary keyword.

Determine the intent of your topic. Search your primary keyword and analyze the pages Google is rewarding.

Ensure you can solve the searcher's problem. Your content should fulfil the searcher's query and solve their problem.

Phase 2: Content

Reverse engineer the current featured snippet and implement your own.

Write your blog post‚Äôs headings (H2-H4) by incorporating the primary and secondary keywords.

Reverse-engineer competitor content and add new headings based on what your competitors are covering.

Look for Google Autosuggest, People Also Ask, and Related Searches to find other search data you can include as headings/sections.

Add new headings and sections based on your knowledge of the topic and information gathered via ICPs.

Make sure the content flows, is skimmable, has good readability, and covers all subtopics.

Ensure images are compressed to <100KB (or as small as possible).

Link to relevant articles and optimize anchor text.

Use bullets, numbered lists, and tables where possible for clarity and readability.

Use short sentences and paragraphs for readability.

Phase 3: Optimization

Include CTAs relevant to the reader's awareness level and search intent.

Add a table of contents to the top of the page for better navigation.

Ensure the title is compelling and includes the primary keyword.

Ensure the URL is short, concise, and includes the primary keyword.

Check if the word count is within 200-400 words higher or lower than the top 1-4 competitor average. If not, ensure your content covers everything.

Write concise and descriptive alt-text for images.

Craft a meta description that is highly relevant to the topic and includes the primary keyword. Ensure it is between 150 and 160 characters and gives a reason for the user to click.

Avoid using the primary keyword more than once in H2-H6 headings to prevent over-optimization. Use secondary keywords and variations instead.

Hook the reader in the introduction by including the topic in the first sentence or paragraph.

Tie the conclusion back to the main topic.

Bold/italicise key text (sentences and/or paragraphs) for emphasis.

Include contextual external links to clarify jargon terms.

Link to any references used to cite your sources.

Run your final draft through an optimisation tool like Clearscope, Surfer, or Frase.

Phase 4: New SEO

posts.text:
We've created 100s of SaaS landing pages that (1) rank in Google and (2) convert traffic into customers.

Here's the landing page plan we follow:

1. Hero section

Company logo: Ensure branding is immediately visible.

Headline: Benefit-driven headline that captures attention and clearly states the (compelling) value proposition.

Subheadline: Supporting statement that adds further clarity to the headline.

Primary CTA: Button that stands out and guides the user to the desired next step.

Social proof: Show that people like the reader are also using the product (and how many).

Image or video: Add an image, video, or GIF that visually communicates the product in action, making it easy for users to understand how it works.

2. Benefits section

Key benefits: Show the main benefits of the product and give a brief description of the features that achieve this.

Supporting visuals: Include images to reinforce the benefits and showcase the product in action.

3. More social proof

Testimonials: Include quotes from satisfied customers to increase authenticity.

Trust signals: Add logos of well-known brands or individual users to further establish credibility.

4. FAQ section

Address the most frequently asked questions to overcome any objections.

Use Google autosuggest, keyword research tools, and search modifiers to find SEO-focused questions to further optimise for your target keyword(s).

5. Final call to action (CTA)

Encourage users to take immediate action.

6. Internal linking

Links to related features: Provide links to other feature pages to keep users exploring.

Make sure to also link to the new landing page from other pages with optimized anchor text.

7. Mobile optimization

Ensure the landing page is fully optimized for mobile users with quick load times, easy navigation, and mobile-friendly CTAs.

8. Footer section

Contact information: Include contact details like email, phone number, and address or a link to support.

Legal information: Provide links to important pages such as Privacy Policy and Terms of Service.

9. Repeat for every feature

We created 8 of these feature pages for a B2B SaaS company several months back.

They now:

- Rank for searches directly looking for their product
- Get 20,000+ "warm" SEO traffic per month

It works.

Yes, SEO takes time.

But the work doesn‚Äôt have to.

Month 1: Strategy

Spend this month researching, learning and planning.

Month 2: Optimize

Spend this month optimizing your existing website.

- Optimize your site structure
- Update your existing content
- Fix technical issues from the audit

Month 3: Content

Spend this month creating and publishing new content.

- Create outlines and briefs for writers

Repeat months 2 and 3 in your next sprint.

96.55% of content gets 0 traffic from Google.

posts.text:
SEO is like weightloss.

There are lots of people and programs promoting and promising quick, life-changing results.

Results aren't instant. You should start seeing good progress after 2-3 months.

The more under-optimized your starting state is, the quicker you should see results.

There's no one solution that fits all. Each case is different and requires a custom-made approach.

But the fundamentals are always the same, and you should work on them simultaneously.

It's simple, but not easy.

You need to create a tailored plan and follow it consistently.

It's all just science.

You have to feed the 'algorithm' the right stuff, and you should stick to healthy strategies only.

Making incremental 1% tweaks can compound and make a huge difference in the long term.

Most people give up too soon.

When you've reached your goal, you can't just stop. You should maintain the habits that have brought you growth.

The first stage of growth is much easier to achieve than the last.

The last stage often requires the most work and only sees smaller, incremental improvements.

Some notable "deaths" include:

- Every Google update

- 15% of searches are brand new
- Searches grow by ~10% every year
- There are 8.5B Google searches daily
- SEO is a $100B+ industry (and growing)
- Search engines and SEO will always evolve
- Search habits will take a long time to change

Block out the noise.

Continue learning, consistently repeating the fundamentals, and adapting to new technologies.

SEO is only ‚Äúdead‚Äù for those who don't.

BOFU Keywords: Using the following keyword frameworks: "{Competitor} Alternatives", "{Competitor} vs {Your Product}" and "Best {Product Category}", provide 10 keywords for each framework for a {your niche} product.

Internal Linking: Read this article on the {keyword} (I will paste it below). Suggest points for internal linking to our previous content {URL1}, {URL2}, {etc}. Propose specific phrases or keywords within the content that can serve as anchor text for internal links. Ensure the anchor text is contextually relevant to the article.

Conversion: Create a list of benefits of {your product or service} in relation to {topic} and describe the positive outcomes for {description of target audience}.

posts.text:
"I don't know how to do SEO"

Start from level 1 in The SEO Game:

To-do lists = Stressful
Game levels = Exhilarating

Reframe your SEO project as a game, and you'll become addicted to levelling up.

Here's my 9-level SEO game:

Level 1: Website Audit

- Crawl your website with Screaming Frog
- Analyze each page and assign actions (delete, 301...)
- Find 'quick win' keywords in GSC (position 3-20)
- Test your page speed in PageSpeed Insights

Level 2: Website Optimization

- Execute technical actions from the audit
- Optimize your 'quick win' keywords from GSC
- Implement internal linking between key pages
- Create lead magnets for pages with existing traffic

Level 3: Competitor Analysis

- Identify your product and SEO competitors
- Enter their domain into Ahrefs (or similar)
- Study (and steal) their SEO strategies
- Conduct a 'gap analysis' vs your site

Level 4: Customer Research

- Send a survey to your customers with key questions
- Take 5 calls with power users to learn their pain points
- Collect customer research from the internet
- Create a document with all your findings

Level 5: Keyword Research

- Create a list of 'seed' keywords for further research
- Export all keywords from Ahrefs from your 'seeds'
- Import keywords in Keyword Insights for clustering
- Select topics to target in your content plan

Level 6: Content Production

- Start at the bottom funnel (comparisons, best of...)
- Move to the middle funnel (how-tos, templates...)
- Scale your top funnel (use Byword for programmatic)

Level 7: Backlink Acquisition

- Reach out to 10 influencers/websites for guest posts
- Create 3 linkable assets (statistics, infographics...)
- Submit your site to 10+ relevant directories/listings
- Track and monitor your backlink profile with Ahrefs

Level 8: Performance Tracking

- Ensure GA tracking and GSC are set up correctly
- Build a Looker Studio dashboard with this data
- Perform monthly competitor benchmarking
- Refine your SEO strategy based on this data

Level 9: Content Tuning

- Monitor your content and 'quick win' keywords
- Update content to better optimize for your topics
- Create lead magnets to convert traffic into emails
- Run A/B tests for CTAs to better convert traffic

Completed all levels?

Start again from level 1. The SEO Game never stops.

PS. Need help levelling up? We‚Äôll turn SEO into a 7-figure sales channel for your business.

posts.text:
How does Google work in 2025?

Search engines are evolving with AI and new algorithms, but the foundations remain the same.

Google has 5 main stages:

1. Crawling: Discover and collect web pages
2. Rendering: Analyze how pages look and function
3. Indexing: Organize and store page information
4. Ranking: Determine relevance and order of pages
5. Querying: Display relevant results for user searches

The diagram below shows this process.

Remember:

If Google can't discover your pages, your content won't be crawled or rendered.

Pages are discovered through:

- The submitted sitemap
- Manual page submission
- Internal links (i.e. hub pages)

If Google can't crawl or render your content, your page won't be indexed.
Possible issues:

- Network issues
- Problems with the server
- Not accessible without logging in
- Robots.txt code preventing access
- Disallowed for crawling by the owner

If Google can't index your page, you won't rank in the search results for relevant queries.

Possible issues:

- Low-quality content
- Irrelevant content to the query
- Code preventing indexing (noindex)
- Design of the site making it difficult

If Google doesn't rank your page, you won't show in Google or get any organic traffic.

SEO helps your website pass each step.

Remember these stages next time you're publishing a page or struggling to rank in Google.

The Anatomy of a perfect blog post:

(Use this checklist)

SEO Metadata:

- Title: Craft a compelling title with your target keywords. Though not a direct ranking factor, it's bolded in search results and should include a call-to-action (CTA).
- Description: Write a descriptive meta that entices clicks, similar to a well-crafted ad.
- URL: Ensure it matches your target keywords. Avoid duplicate page structures and refrain from including years in URLs.

Schema Markup:

- Implement schema types like Article, BlogPosting, and Breadcrumbs for enhanced SERP presentation.

Original Images:

- Every image should have an Alt attribute for SEO and accessibility.

Content-Length:

- Aim for a minimum of 700 words, adjusting based on competition and query specificity.

Able of Contents with Jump Links:

- Utilize anchor links for easy navigation. Google indexes these, enhancing user experience (UX) and providing valuable data.

Heading Structure:

- Follow a proper format with a single H1 and supporting text under each heading. Use H3s and H4s appropriately.

Internal Links:

- Ensure every page has internal links leading to and from it. This aids in crawl efficiency and contextual relevance.

Product Card Embeds:

- Embed product cards to increase CTR. Test different CTAs, especially for high-traffic articles.

HTML Elements:

- Use lists, tables, and accordions to capture featured snippets and improve UX metrics like session duration.

YouTube Video Embed:

- Ideally, pair each blog post with a complementary YouTube video. Embedding videos can serve as backlinks and enhance visibility on both Google and YouTube.

CTA for Engagement:

- Encourage user engagement with clear CTAs. This can lead to better interaction metrics and conversions.

Check off each one of these when creating your blog post. And you'll not just be writing content.

You'll be crafting an experience that resonates with your readers and search engines alike.

posts.text:
My 31-step SEO checklist for creating new blog posts:

Phase 1: Topic Research

Identify the primary keyword for your topic. This is typically the most popular keyword related to your topic.

Identify the secondary keywords for your topic. These are keywords closely related to your primary keyword.

Determine the intent of your topic. Search your primary keyword and analyze the pages Google is rewarding.

Ensure you can solve the searcher's problem. Your content should fulfil the searcher's query and solve their problem.

Phase 2: Content

Reverse engineer the current featured snippet and implement your own.

Write your blog post‚Äôs headings (H2-H4) by incorporating the primary and secondary keywords.

Reverse-engineer competitor content and add new headings based on what your competitors are covering.

Look for Google Autosuggest, People Also Ask, and Related Searches to find other search data you can include as headings/sections.

Add new headings and sections based on your knowledge of the topic and information gathered via ICPs.

Make sure the content flows, is skimmable, has good readability, and covers all subtopics.

Ensure images are compressed to <100KB (or as small as possible).

Link to relevant articles and optimize anchor text.

Use bullets, numbered lists, and tables where possible for clarity and readability.

Use short sentences and paragraphs for readability.

Phase 3: Optimization

Include CTAs relevant to the reader's awareness level and search intent.

Add a table of contents to the top of the page for better navigation.

Ensure the title is compelling and includes the primary keyword.

Ensure the URL is short, concise, and includes the primary keyword.

Check if the word count is within 200-400 words higher or lower than the top 1-4 competitor average. If not, ensure your content covers everything.

Write concise and descriptive alt-text for images.

Craft a meta description that is highly relevant to the topic and includes the primary keyword. Ensure it is between 150 and 160 characters and gives a reason for the user to click.

Avoid using the primary keyword more than once in H2-H6 headings to prevent over-optimization. Use secondary keywords and variations instead.

Hook the reader in the introduction by including the topic in the first sentence or paragraph.

Tie the conclusion back to the main topic.

Bold/italicise key text (sentences and/or paragraphs) for emphasis.

Include contextual external links to clarify jargon terms.

Link to any references used to cite your sources.

Run your final draft through an optimization tool like Clearscope, Surfer, or Frase.

Phase 4: New SEO

posts.text:
The top 1% of SEOs know these writing practices:

Title Tag:

- Use it only for the main headline
- Include the primary keyword (ideally at the start)
- Keep titles unique and compelling to avoid content cannibalization

URL:

- Incorporate the primary keyword phrase
- Keep URLs short and avoid repeating keywords across different URLs

Headings (H1, H2, H3):

- Structure content with H1s, H2s, and H3s in a hierarchy for better crawlability
- H1s should contain the main keyword, H2s for long-tail keywords in multi-section articles, H3s for subtopics

Internal Linking:

- Add relevant internal links (aim for one link per 200 words)
- Use descriptive anchor text related to the target article

Meta Descriptions:

- Include primary and secondary keywords
- Craft descriptions to encourage click-throughs without keyword stuffing

Images:

- Use original images for better ranking
- Ensure ALT text includes primary and secondary keywords but remains descriptive and unique
- Name media files with the primary keyword

User Experience:

- Break up large text blocks for readability
- Utilize bullets, lists, and headings
- Embed relevant YouTube videos to enhance content with multimedia, improving page dwell time

Avoid Duplicate Content:

- Ensure content uniqueness within your site
- Update old articles by adding new sections rather than subtracting content (unless correcting inaccuracies)

Captivating Openers:

- Use questions, narratives, research findings, or unexpected claims to grab attention (but keep some information withheld to spark curiosity)

posts.text:
An unbeatable SEO strategy needs to balance:

Content that resonates with your ICP and technical expertise.

But what factors make this work?

On-site factors:

1. Content

- Quality and Depth: high-quality, comprehensive content improves rankings by effectively answering queries.
- Keywords: relevant keywords aid search engines in matching content with searches.
- Freshness: regular updates keep content relevant, especially for evolving topics.
- Multimedia: images and videos boost user engagement, positively impacting SEO.
- Answers: directly answering questions can lead to featured snippets in search results.

2. HTML

- Title Tags and Meta Descriptions: These provide content summaries to users and search engines, influencing click-through rates.
- Headings: Organize content and clarify its structure for search engines.
- Structure: Well-structured HTML enhances content indexing and crawling.
- Site Health: Factors like broken links and tag usage affect site quality assessments.

3. Architecture

- URLs: Clear, descriptive URLs improve user experience and content understanding.
- Crawlability: Essential for content indexing and ranking.
- Mobile Experience: Crucial for rankings due to prevalent mobile usage.
- Internal Linking: Distributes page authority and aids navigation.
- Speed: Faster load times enhance user experience and SEO.

Off-site factors:

1. Trust

- User Signals: Time on site, bounce rate, and click-through rate reflect site quality and relevance.
- Authority: Measured by the quality of backlinks, indicating trustworthiness.
- Social Signals: Increase visibility and can indirectly impact rankings.
- Personalization: Affects how content is displayed based on user behavior and location.

2. Links

- Quality: Links from reputable sources enhance site authority and ranking.
- Quantity: A large number of backlinks suggests popularity, but quality is more crucial.
- Anchor Text: Relevant anchor text helps search engines understand linked content.

Each of these factors affect how search engines evaluate and rank your website.

Balancing them effectively will lead to better SEO performance.

posts.text:
I've created 100s of SaaS landing pages that (1) rank in Google and (2) convert traffic into customers.

Here's the exact landing page plan I follow:

1. Hero section

Company logo: Ensure branding is immediately visible.

Headline: Benefit-driven headline that captures attention and clearly states the (compelling) value proposition.

Subheadline: Supporting statement that adds further clarity to the headline.

Primary CTA: Button that stands out and guides the user to the desired next step.

Social proof: Show that people like the reader are also using the product (and how many).

Image or video: Add an image, video, or GIF that visually communicates the product in action, making it easy for users to understand how it works.

2. Benefits section

Key benefits: Show the main benefits of the product and give a brief description of the features that achieve this.

Supporting visuals: Include images to reinforce the benefits and showcase the product in action.

3. More social proof

Testimonials: Include quotes from satisfied customers to increase authenticity.

Trust signals: Add logos of well-known brands or individual users to further establish credibility.

4. FAQ section

Address the most frequently asked questions to overcome any objections.

Use Google autosuggest, keyword research tools, and search modifiers to find SEO-focused questions to further optimize for your target keyword(s).

5. Final call to action (CTA)

Encourage users to take immediate action.

6. Internal linking

Links to related features: Provide links to other feature pages to keep users exploring.

Make sure to also link to the new landing page from other pages with optimized anchor text.

7. Mobile optimization

Ensure the landing page is fully optimized for mobile users with quick load times, easy navigation, and mobile-friendly CTAs.

8. Footer section

Contact information: Include contact details like email, phone number, and address or a link to support.

Legal information: Provide links to important pages such as Privacy Policy and Terms of Service.

9. Repeat for every feature

We created 8 of these feature pages for a B2B SaaS company a few months back.

They now:

- Rank for searches directly looking for their product
- Get 20,000+ "warm" SEO traffic per month

It works.

posts.text:
17 most common SEO issues we find:

(That can be easily fixed)

1. Duplicate Content: Having the same or very similar content on multiple pages can negatively impact SEO.

2. Broken Links: Links that lead nowhere or to error pages create a bad user experience and can harm SEO.

3. Slow Page Load Times: Slow-loading pages can frustrate users and negatively affect search engine rankings.

4. Old Publish Dates: Avoid older dates showing up against recently published or updated content. This hurts your CTR and your rankings

5. Thin Content: Pages with very little useful content are often ranked lower by search engines.

6. Missing Alt Tags and Broken Images: Images without alt tags or broken images can affect SEO as they contribute to the overall content quality and accessibility.

7. Unoptimized Meta Descriptions and Titles: Titles and descriptions that are not optimized for keywords and readability can impact click-through rates and rankings.

8. Improper Use of Header Tags: Not using header tags (H1, H2, etc.) correctly can make it harder for search engines to understand the structure and content of a page.

9. Lack of Quality Backlinks: Not having enough high-quality backlinks can affect a site's authority and ranking.

10. Poor User Experience (UX): Websites that are difficult to navigate or unengaging can lead to high bounce rates, which can negatively impact SEO.

11. Overuse of Keywords (Keyword Stuffing): Excessively using keywords can lead to penalties from search engines for spammy behavior.

12. Not Using Structured Data (Schema Markup): Failing to implement structured data can result in missed opportunities to enhance search result listings and improve click-through rates.

13. Inconsistent NAP (Name, Address, Phone Number) for Local SEO: Inconsistencies in business listings can harm local SEO efforts.

14. Ignoring Social Signals: While not a direct ranking factor, social signals (like shares and likes) can indirectly affect SEO by increasing visibility and traffic.

15. Image Pages in WordPress: Every image uploaded may have its own page, which Google indexes. Plugins like Yoast can redirect attachment URLs to the image, maintaining a clean site footprint.

16. HTTP Pages: Ensure all pages are secure (HTTPS). Use the ‚Äòsite:domain inurl:-https‚Äô search command to find non-secure pages.

17. Unintended Indexed Pages: Perform a site:domain search with terms like ‚ÄúLorem ipsum,‚Äù ‚ÄúPortfolio,‚Äù ‚ÄúDemo,‚Äù ‚ÄúIndex,‚Äù ‚ÄúError,‚Äù ‚ÄúTest,‚Äù or a blank search to find and address low-quality pages.

What other common SEO issues would you add?

The 4 crucial E-E-A-T pillars for ranking in Google:

- Experience
- Expertise
- Authoritativeness
- Trustworthiness

Let's break them down:

1. Experience

What it means: Your content should reflect first-hand experiences on the topic.

How to optimize: Showcase the faces behind your website. An "About Us" page detailing your team's credentials can be invaluable.

2. Expertise

What it means: The depth of knowledge demonstrated in your content.

How to optimize: Include author bios with relevant qualifications and links to social media profiles.

3. Authoritativeness

What it means: Being a go-to source on the topic.

How to optimize: Build a solid content architecture and earn backlinks from other authoritative sites.

4. Trustworthiness

What it means: Earning user trust through experience, expertise, and authoritativeness.

How to optimize: Maintain a professional-looking site, update content regularly, and avoid errors.

Focus on these 4 pillars to rank well in Google and provide real value to your audience.

posts.text:
The best SEO masterclass you'll see this week.

7 strategies behind Canva's dominance:

- 260M monthly traffic
- 35M backlinks
- 190 target countries
- $100Ms SEO revenue
- $26B valuation

1. Programmatic SEO

Canva created 1,000s of SEO-focused pages at scale.

They're divided into 3 main categories:

- Builder (e.g. Resume Builder or Logo Maker)
- Templates (e.g. YouTube Banner Template)
- Create (e.g. Create Logo or Create CV)

These pages alone get 100M+ monthly SEO traffic.

And even a low 1% conversion rate acquires at least 1M new Canva users a month.

2. Product-Led Conversions

Canva converts traffic by providing tools to create what the user has searched for, directly on the page, with ready-made templates inside the product.

This aligns with their freemium model:

A. Converts traffic to start using the platform right away (on the highly valuable free plan).

B. Free plan users later upgrade to a paid plan to unlock even more features.

3. Content Clusters

Canva created groups of related pages that build topical authority around specific design topics.

For example:

Subfolder: /colors
Page: /colors/color-meanings
Subpage: /colors/color-meanings/blue

This is how you dominate your search market.

The 'Colors' cluster alone has 3.8K pages, all interlinked, which generates 2M monthly SEO traffic.

4. Internal Linking

Canva ensures that high-authority pages pass ‚Äòauthority‚Äô to relevant subpages through internal linking.

For example:

High authority page: Flyer Templates
Subpage link: Restaurant Flyer Templates

That single link makes the subpage rank.

5. Backlinks

Canva has 35M backlinks from 338K websites, resulting in a 93 Domain Rating.

Standard outreach and PR aside...

Here are 3 strategies they used to EARN backlinks:

A. Link-worthy content

High-quality content that other websites cite.

For example:

Page: Ultimate Guide to Font Combinations
Backlinks: 2.8K (organically)

B. App integrations

New apps consistently get listed on Canva.

These apps often create content around their Canva integration, which results in a backlink.

C. Acquisitions

Canva bought these websites:

Pexels: DR 92
Affinity: DR 82
Pixabay: DR 92
Flourish: DR 84
Leonardo: DR 76
Designify: DR 48
Unscreen: DR 65
Remove bg: DR 81
Smartmockups: DR 67

Now they all link to Canva's website.

Reminder: Build backlinks from all your owned websites. These are the easiest links you'll get.

6. Localised and Multilingual SEO

Canva localised versions of their website to target all languages and regions, making them a global behemoth.

For example:

Latin America = 34M monthly traffic
Indonesia = 12M monthly traffic
Brazil = 15M monthly traffic

7. Trending Content

Canva keeps up with trends to drive traffic for current high-demand, low-competition keywords.

For example:

During the pandemic, the search demand for 'Zoom Backgrounds' skyrocketed.

New page: Free Zoom Background Templates
Result: 100K+ new monthly SEO traffic

Who should I break down next?

posts.text:
Your 2025 SEO strategy checklist:

Phase 1: Audit

Crawl your website with a tool like Screaming Frog (connect GA/GSC/other data) and export as a CSV.

Enter each URL into Search Console or Ahrefs and find its best-ranking keywords. Add them to your spreadsheet.

Audit each blog post and assign actions (Leave, Merge, Delete, Update, Rewrite).

Phase 2: Quick Wins

Identify technical fixes in your audit like internal linking, canonical tags, 301 redirects, sitemap, etc.

Find ways to optimize your existing pages for the keywords found in your audit (new sections, updates, headings, snippets/AI Overviews).

Phase 3: Customer Research

Talk to, survey and/or interview your customers to learn:

- Problems before finding your product
- Features they bought it for (and use)
- Why your product vs other solutions
- Other solutions they considered
- How it solves their problems

Phase 4: Topic Research

Enter your competitors' websites in a tool like Ahrefs and export their keywords to reverse-engineer their SEO.

Identify ‚Äòseed‚Äô keywords from your customer research and use general brainstorming to start your research.

Enter your ‚Äòseeds‚Äô into a tool like Ahrefs and use the ‚ÄòMatching terms‚Äô report to find topics to target.

Identify topics to build landing pages around the different features or solutions your product offers.

Identify bottom funnel topics like competitor comparisons, competitor alternatives, and best-of guides.

Identify middle funnel topics like how-to guides, templates, tips, and anything relating to customer problems.

Identify top funnel topics like glossaries (e.g. ‚Äòwhat is X'), topic vs topic, ‚Äòideas‚Äô lists, and anything to capture awareness.

Phase 5: Content Plan

Collate all identified topics into a simple spreadsheet to execute over the following months.

Prioritize your content ideas by ease of ranking, commercial intent and potential traffic.

Strategy done.

- Fix your technical issues
- Optimize your existing content
- Create new content from your plan
- Scale content production with AI (like Byword)

And don‚Äôt stop.

Client: 300+ blog posts. 1K/mo (declining) traffic.

Our team: 0 new blog posts. 120K/mo traffic.

How? Content optimization.

Here's the background:

The client published 300+ blog posts over 2 years but only had ~1K/mo traffic (which was declining).

They had invested 6-figures into their blog and wanted to get more out of their existing content.

Here's what we did:

1. Content audit

We identified:

- Posts nearly ranking (low-hanging fruit)
- Posts with potential but poorly optimized
- Posts without any value to users or Google
- Posts targeting multiple 'intents' to separate
- Posts on the same topic that could be merged

We prioritized the posts based on getting the quickest increase in traffic possible.

2. Content optimization

We optimized content that had potential (~20%).

For each post, we focused on:

- Introduction
- Internal linking
- Word presence
- Topic coverage
- Matching intent
- Term frequency
- Featured snippets
- Content structure

We completed this over a 90-day sprint.

We hit 120K+ per month in 180 days.

Soon after, we started publishing new content and quickly surpassed 150K+/mo SEO traffic.

posts.text:
Social media marketing vs search marketing:

(8 ways they are complete opposites)

Social users don‚Äôt have a plan.
Search users are taking action.

Social posts are typically short-form.
Search typically requires longer-form.

Social gets instant results after publishing.
Search results are delayed after publishing.

Social algorithms are focused on engagement.
Search algorithms are focused on relevance.

Social posts typically lose visibility after hours.
Search provides consistent and long-term traffic.

Social needs to align with the interests of followers.
Search needs to align with the intent of searchers.

Social gets fewer conversions but more awareness.
Search gets more conversions if you fulfil the query.

Social has viral potential as there‚Äôs no limit to reach.
Search traffic won‚Äôt exceed the number of searches.

They are complete opposites.

But when done right, they work incredibly well together.

Here's how:

- Create long-form content for SEO
- Repurpose and distribute it for socials
- Convert readers to email subscribers on both

That way, you leverage:

- Instant visibility with socials
- Long-term visibility with SEO
- Direct communication with email

What other differences would you add?

Google is the best source of SEO insights.

But only if you use these 12 search operators:

1. ‚Äúkeyword‚Äù = Exact-match search
2. site: = View indexed pages for a specific site
3. intitle: = View pages with specific text in titles
4. allintitle: = Like the above, but contains all text
5. inurl: = View pages with specific text in URLs
6. allinurl: = Like the above, but contains all text
7. OR = Get results for {operator} OR {operator2}
8. AND = Get results for {operator} AND {operator2}
9. - (minus) = Exclude specific operators
10. related: = Find related sites to a specific URL
11. cache: = View the most recently cached page
12. filetype: = View certain filetypes (PDF, DOCX...)

Simple searches can help you find insights for:

- Link building
- Internal linking
- Technical audits
- Content strategy
- Competitor research

posts.text:
SEO is like weightloss.

There are lots of people and programs promoting and promising quick, life-changing results.

Results aren't instant. You should start seeing good progress after 2-3 months.

The more under-optimized your starting state is, the quicker you should see results.

There's no one solution that fits all. Each case is different and requires a custom-made approach.

But the fundamentals are always the same, and you should work on them simultaneously.

It's simple, but not easy.

You need to create a tailored plan and follow it consistently.

It's all just science.

You have to feed the 'algorithm' the right stuff, and you should stick to healthy strategies only.

Making incremental 1% tweaks can compound and make a huge difference in the long term.

Most people give up too soon.

When you've reached your goal, you can't just stop. You should maintain the habits that have brought you growth.

The first stage of growth is much easier to achieve than the last.

The last stage often requires the most work and only sees smaller, incremental improvements.

Planning new SEO content for 2025?

1. Get all your blog URLs into a spreadsheet.

Connect further data sources:

- Ahrefs
- Google Analytics
- Google Search Console

2. Enter each URL into Google Search Console or Ahrefs and find its best-ranking keywords.

Add this data to the spreadsheet for each page:

- Primary keyword (your main keyword)
- Secondary keywords (variations and similar)
- Current position for your target keyword(s)

If a URL isn't ranking for anything?

Find the most relevant keywords using Ahrefs.

3. Audit each blog post and assign actions:

- Leave: Content that‚Äôs reached its full potential
- Merge: Cannibalising or extremely similar content
- Delete: Content that no longer offers value to users
- Update: Small changes to improve the performance
- Rewrite: Large changes to improve the performance

4. Spend a few weeks in Q1 implementing these actions to get more out of your existing assets.

Prioritise updates and rewrites that have:

- Target keywords in positions 4-20
- Higher conversion and $ potential
- Easy improvement opportunities

Remember:

Not all of your Q1 content needs to be new. Look at your existing content first.

You're likely sitting on many quick wins.

"I don't know how to do SEO"

Start from level 1 in The SEO Game:

To-do lists = Stressful

Game levels = Exhilarating

Reframe your SEO project as a game, and you'll become addicted to levelling up.

Here's my 9-level SEO game:

Level 1: Website Audit

- Crawl your website with Screaming Frog
- Analyse each page and assign actions (delete, 301...)
- Find 'quick win' keywords in GSC (position 3-20)
- Test your page speed in PageSpeed Insights

Level 2: Website Optimisation

- Execute technical actions from the audit
- Optimise your 'quick win' keywords from GSC
- Implement internal linking between key pages
- Create lead magnets for pages with existing traffic

Level 3: Competitor Analysis

- Identify your product and SEO competitors
- Enter their domain into Ahrefs (or similar)
- Study (and steal) their SEO strategies
- Conduct a 'gap analysis' vs your site

Level 4: Customer Research

- Send a survey to your customers with key questions
- Take 5 calls with power users to learn their pain points
- Collect customer research from the internet
- Create a document with all your findings

Level 5: Keyword Research

- Create a list of 'seed' keywords for further research
- Export all keywords from Ahrefs from your 'seeds'
- Import keywords in Keyword Insights for clustering
- Select topics to target in your content plan

Level 6: Content Production

- Start at the bottom funnel (comparisons, best of...)
- Move to the middle funnel (how-tos, templates...)
- Scale your top funnel (use Byword for programmatic)

Level 7: Backlink Acquisition

- Reach out to 10 influencers/websites for guest posts
- Create 3 linkable assets (statistics, infographics...)
- Submit your site to 10+ relevant directories/listings
- Track and monitor your backlink profile with Ahrefs

Level 8: Performance Tracking

- Ensure GA tracking and GSC are set up correctly
- Build a Looker Studio dashboard with this data
- Perform monthly competitor benchmarking
- Refine your SEO strategy based on this data

Level 9: Content Tuning

- Monitor your content and 'quick win' keywords
- Update content to better optimise for your topics
- Create lead magnets to convert traffic into emails
- Run A/B tests for CTAs to better convert traffic

Completed all levels?

Start again from level 1. The SEO Game never ends.

30-step SEO checklist for optimising content:

(follow it and you WILL increase traffic)

Phase 1: Audit

Which pages and keywords do you need to optimise?
‚Ü≥ Identify pages declining in performance
‚Ü≥ Focus on keywords nearly ranking (positions 3-20)

Are you matching the intent?
‚Ü≥ Match the content type (e.g. blog vs landing page)
‚Ü≥ Match the content format (e.g. how-to vs list)

Can you do better than the current top 3 results?

Phase 2: Filling Gaps

What have your competitors covered that you haven‚Äôt?

What topics or entities are you missing (i.e. NLP terms)?
‚Ü≥ Use tools like Surfer or Frase to identify topic gaps

Can you write new sentences, paragraphs, or sections around the keywords you‚Äôre nearly ranking for?

What other search data can you include as new sections to rank for even more searches?
‚Ü≥ Analyse autosuggest, People Also Ask, and related searches directly in the SERP

Phase 3: Improvements

Do you have new data or info from customers, interviews, or similar that you can include to make the content even better?

Is the content organised in an optimal structure?
‚Ü≥ Ensure it flows, it‚Äôs skimmable, covers all subtopics, and has a good readability experience

Have you used enough images or other media (i.e. showing product in action)?

Have you used numbered or bullet lists where possible?

Have you used tables where possible?

Have you used short sentences and paragraphs, and removed any fluff?

Should you add a table of contents to the top of the page?

Phase 4: Optimisation

Does your introduction hook the reader and include you target topic or keyword in the content?

Have you included the topic (to tie it back) in the conclusion or final section?

Can you optimise the headings using your target keyword(s)?

Have you over-optimised for the target keyword by using it more than once in headings?
‚Ü≥ Ensure you avoid keyword stuffing

Have you boldened the key text (sentences and/or paragraphs)?
‚Ü≥ Use bold and italics to emphasise important text

Is there a featured snippet you can win? If so, how?

Can you make the meta title more compelling for higher CTR?

Can you make your meta description more compelling to click?

Does your image alt-text concisely explain what the images are?

What relevant pages can you internally link from?

Are there any pages you can link to?

Are you including CTAs relevant to the reader‚Äôs awareness level or search intent?

Phase 5: ‚ÄúNew‚Äù SEO

Have you optimised for Google‚Äôs AI Overview?
‚Ü≥ Structure your content to be easily summarised by AI
‚Ü≥ Focus on concise answers and bullet points

Have you incorporated EEAT (Experience, Expertise, Authoritativeness, Trustworthiness)?
‚Ü≥ Highlight author credentials and link to authoritative sources to build trust

Have you adapted headings for voice search?
‚Ü≥ Use conversational language and question headings

Have you optimised for multi-device usability?
‚Ü≥  Ensure content is accessible and user-friendly across different devices

posts.text:
How does Google work going into 2025?

Search engines are evolving with AI and new algorithms, but the foundations remain the same.

Google has 5 main stages:

1. Crawling: Discover and collect web pages
2. Rendering: Analyse how pages look and function
3. Indexing: Organise and store page information
4. Ranking: Determine relevance and order of pages
5. Querying: Display relevant results for user searches

We‚Äôve created the diagram below to show this process.

Remember:

If Google can't discover your pages, your content won't be crawled or rendered.

Pages are discovered through:

- The submitted sitemap
- Manual page submission
- Internal links (i.e. hub pages)

If Google can't crawl or render your content, your page won't be indexed.

Possible issues:

- Network issues
- Problems with the server
- Not accessible without logging in
- Robots.txt code preventing access
- Disallowed for crawling by the owner

If Google can't index your page, you won't rank in the search results for relevant queries.

Possible issues:

- Low-quality content
- Irrelevant content to the query
- Code preventing indexing (noindex)
- Design of the site making it difficult

If Google doesn't rank your page, you won't show in Google or get any organic traffic.

SEO helps your website pass each step.

Remember these stages next time you're publishing a page or struggling to rank in Google.

posts.text:
Our 31-step SEO checklist for creating blog posts:

(Follow it and you WILL get traffic)

Phase 1: Topic Research

Identify the primary keyword for your topic. This is typically the most popular keyword related to your topic.

Identify the secondary keywords for your topic. These are keywords closely related to your primary keyword.

Determine the intent of your topic. Search your primary keyword and analyse the pages Google is rewarding.

Ensure you can solve the searcher's problem. Your content should fulfil the searcher's query and solve their problem.
 


Phase 2: Content

Reverse engineer the current featured snippet and implement your own.

Write your blog post‚Äôs headings (H2-H4) by incorporating the primary and secondary keywords.

Reverse-engineer competitor content and add new headings based on what your competitors are covering.

Look for Google Autosuggest, People Also Ask, and Related Searches to find other search data you can include as headings/sections.

Add new headings and sections based on your knowledge of the topic and information gathered via ICPs.

Make sure the content flows, is skimmable, has good readability, and covers all subtopics.

Ensure images are compressed to <100KB (or as small as possible).

Link to relevant articles and optimise anchor text.

Use bullets, numbered lists, and tables where possible for clarity and readability.

Use short sentences and paragraphs for readability.
 


Phase 3: Optimisation

Include CTAs relevant to the reader's awareness level and search intent.

Add a table of contents to the top of the page for better navigation.

Ensure the title is compelling and includes the primary keyword.

Ensure the URL is short, concise, and includes the primary keyword.

Check if the word count is within 200-400 words higher or lower than the top 1-4 competitor average. If not, ensure your content covers everything.

Write concise and descriptive alt-text for images.

Craft a meta description that is highly relevant to the topic and includes the primary keyword. Ensure it is between 150 and 160 characters and gives a reason for the user to click.

Avoid using the primary keyword more than once in H2-H6 headings to prevent over-optimisation. Use secondary keywords and variations instead.

Hook the reader in the introduction by including the topic in the first sentence or paragraph.

Tie the conclusion back to the main topic.

Bold/italicise key text (sentences and/or paragraphs) for emphasis.

Include contextual external links to clarify jargon terms.

Link to any references used to cite your sources.

Run your final draft through an optimisation tool like Clearscope, Surfer, or Frase.
 
Phase 4: New SEO

author.headline: Helping brands get rankings and revenue from Google, LLMs, AI Overviews | CEO of Contact.so | Mentions.so | Kleo.so

document.title: How to optimise for AI Overviews

posted_at.relative: 1 year ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
We've created 100s of SaaS landing pages that (1) rank in Google and (2) convert traffic into customers.

Here's the landing page plan we follow:

1. Hero section

Company logo: Ensure branding is immediately visible.

Headline: Benefit-driven headline that captures attention and clearly states the (compelling) value proposition.

E.g. "Discover and create the best LinkedIn content"

Subheadline: Supporting statement that adds further clarity to the headline.

E.g. "Kleo is the free browser extension that helps you easily find inspiration and create content on LinkedIn."

Primary CTA: Button that stands out and guides the user to the desired next step.

E.g. "Install on Chrome"

Social proof: Show that people like the reader are also using the product (and how many).

E.g. "Loved by 27,000 LinkedIn users" (include visuals like user images or logos)

Image or video: Add an image, video, or GIF that visually communicates the product in action, making it easy for users to understand how it works.

2. Benefits section

Key benefits: Show the main benefits of the product and give a brief description of the features that achieve this.

E.g. "Study any creator‚Äôs content. Zoom in on your favourite creators to get better insight into their content and standout posts."

Supporting visuals: Include images to reinforce the benefits and showcase the product in action.

3. More social proof

Testimonials: Include quotes from satisfied customers to increase authenticity.

Trust signals: Add logos of well-known brands or individual users to further establish credibility.

E.g. "Trusted by 1,000+ teams worldwide"

4. FAQ section

Address the most frequently asked questions to overcome any objections.
E.g. "Is Kleo detected by LinkedIn?"

Use Google autosuggest, keyword research tools, and search modifiers to find SEO-focused questions to further optimise for your target keyword(s).

E.g. "Why is Kleo the best LinkedIn content tool?"

5. Final call to action (CTA)

Encourage users to take immediate action.

E.g. "Start using Kleo for free"

6. Internal linking

Links to related features: Provide links to other feature pages to keep users exploring.

E.g. ‚ÄúSee how you can preview posts with Kleo"

Make sure to also link to the new landing page from other pages with optimised anchor text.

7. Mobile optimisation

Ensure the landing page is fully optimised for mobile users with quick load times, easy navigation, and mobile-friendly CTAs.

8. Footer section

Contact information: Include contact details like email, phone number, and address or a link to support.

Legal information: Provide links to important pages such as Privacy Policy and Terms of Service.

9. Repeat for every feature

We created 8 of these feature pages for a B2B SaaS company a few months ago.

They now:

- Rank for searches directly looking for their product
- Get 20,000+ "warm" SEO traffic per month

It really works.

posts.text:
Client: 300+ blog posts. 1K/mo (declining) traffic.

Our team: 0 new blog posts. 120K/mo traffic.

How? Content optimisation.

Here's the background:

The client published 300+ blog posts over 2 years but only had ~1K/mo traffic (which was declining).

They had invested 6-figures into their blog and wanted to get more out of their existing content.

Here's what we did:

1. Content audit

We identified:

- Posts nearly ranking (low-hanging fruit)
- Posts with potential but poorly optimised
- Posts without any value to users or Google
- Posts targeting multiple 'intents' to separate
- Posts on the same topic that could be merged

We prioritised the posts based on getting the quickest increase in traffic possible.

2. Content optimisation

We optimised content that had potential (~20%).

For each post, we focused on:

- Introduction
- Internal linking
- Word presence
- Topic coverage
- Matching intent
- Term frequency
- Featured snippets
- Content structure

We completed this over a 90-day sprint.

We hit 120K+ per month in 180 days.

Soon after, we started publishing new content and quickly surpassed 150K+/mo SEO traffic.

Do you want to turn SEO into a 7-figure sales channel?
